labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Automations tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page gives you an overview of your Automations in three tabs:
  • The first tab called Workflows is a tabular list of the workflows (active or not) t
  • The second tab called Process builders is a tabular list of the process builders (active or not)
  • The third tab called Flows is a tabular list of the flows (whatever their type)

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Batches tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page gives you an overview of your Batches in three tabs:
  • The first tab called Schedulable classes not yet scheduled is giving you the list of classes that could be deleted because not scheduled in this org
  • The second tab called Apex Jobs is a tabular list of the apex jobs from YESTERDAY that actually completed or failed (not the pending ones).
  • The third tab called Scheduled Jobs is a tabular list of the CRONed tasks

Issues or new ideas?
Track them at
sfdc.co/OrgCheck-Backlog

Want to chat with other users?
Please join us on Slack with this invitation

Social Media
Like and share posts on LinkedIn and on Twitter !

OrgCheck is free to use, but is not an official Salesforce product. OrgCheck has not been officially tested or documented. Salesforce support is not available for OrgCheck. Support requests for OrgCheck should be directed to GitHub at https://github.com/VinceFINET/OrgCheck/issues . Source code for OrgCheck can be found at https://github.com/VinceFINET/OrgCheck under separate and different license terms.

My vision of this tool was (and still is):
  • The tool should run on a salesforce org: easy to install and easy to use
  • No additional software or platform
  • No need to have a Salesforce Employee with her/his magical access
  • Code of the application is available you can modify it, if you need it

This page is showing (as a first beta version) a tabular view of all CRUDs for each Profile/PermSet and Objects.

As this (beta) approach could be time consuming when loading the page, we disabled this feature by default.

If you want to test this feature, go to the home page and unselect the preference Do not fetch the CRUDs on profiles and permission sets

In the future, this page will let you select the profile(s)/permission set(s) and/or the objects before retrieving the data.

labels.shortDescription: Subtitle of the Objects tab in OrgCheck
Title of the Objects tab in OrgCheck
Description / Help text of the Visual Components tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
On all the tables:
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the item is not used by any other entity (based on the Dependency API), then you get +1.
    2. When applicable, if the API version used by the item is older than three years, then you get +1.
    3. If the item has no description, then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words, the biggest scores come first.
  • If the item has dependencies, you can click on the link "Dependencies" to get a graphical view of where it is used and what it is using.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Apex tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
On the Classes table:
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the class is not used by any other entity (based on the Dependency API), then you get +1.
    2. If the API version of the class is older thayearsyear, then you get +1.
    3. If the class needs recompilation, then you get +1.
    4. If the class is not explicitly specifying the sharing, then you get +1.
    5. If the class has not reached coveragevergare of 85% , then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words, the biggest scores come first.
  • If the item has dependencies, you can click on the link "Dependencies" to get a graphical view of where it is used and what it is using.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Roles tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
On the graphical view:
  • Each box represents a role that are linked to each other following their parent role.
  • The yellow boxes represent roles without any active users
  • The blue boxes represent roles with active users
  • On each box, you can see bubbles in their upper right corner
  • The blue bubbles represent the number of active users (if more than 100 we put 99+)
  • The grey bubbles represent the number of inactive users (if more than 100 we put 99+)
  • You can click on each box to get more details about the corresponding role.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Profiles and Permission Sets tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
On the permission sets table:
  • Each row represents a permissio set or a permission set group
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If it is custom and is not used by any active users, then you get +1.
    2. If it is custom and has no description, then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.

At this time, the Object CRUDs are shown as a beta feature that needs to be activated on the Home tab of this application.
We did this to make sure this feature is not slowing you down.
In the future, you will be able to select either the object(s) or the profile(s)/permission set(s).

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Profiles and Permission Sets tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
On the profiles table:
  • Each row represents a profile which can be custom or standard
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If it is custom and is not used by any active users, then you get +1.
    2. If it is custom and has no description, then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Public Groups tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
On the public groups table:
  • Each row represents a public group
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the public group contains no active user at all (see All Active Users column), then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.

On the queues table:
  • Each row represents a queue
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the queue contains no active user at all (see All Active Users column), then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Roles tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
On the tabular table view:
  • Each row represents a role
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the role contains no active user, then you get +1.
    2. If the role contains more than one inactive user, then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Apex tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
On the Triggers per object table:
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the count of active triggers per object is greater that one, you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Apex tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
On the Triggers table:
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the trigger is not used by any other entity (based on the Dependency API), then you get +1.
    2. If the API version of the trigger is older than 3 year, then you get +1.
    3. If the trigger is inactive, then you get +1.
    4. If the trigger is more than 5,000 characters long, then you get +1.
    5. If the trigger is containing SOQL or DML statments, then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.
  • If the item has dependencies, you can click on the link "Dependencies" to get a graphical view of where it is used and what it is using.
On which entity do you wish to have information?

labels.shortDescription: Text of the section #5 in home page
labels.value:
OrgCheck scans the org where it has been installed

On the top of each page, you will see the org id (in a green badge) being used by OrgCheck. The org Id starts with 00D.
Please note that we get dependencies only for custom fields and not standard fields. Thank you!

Subtitle #2 in section #3 in home page
Description / Help text of the Objects tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page gives you an overview of your Objects in two tabs:
  • The first tab called Object Documentation is giving you the entire documentatio of a specified object
  • The second tab called Org Wide Default is a tabular list of the internal and external sharing for all your objects

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Roles tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page illustrates your Role Hierarchy in two tabs:
  • The first tab called Role Explorer is showing a graphical view of your role hierarchy
  • The second tab called Role Listing is a tabular list of the corresponding data.

Too many levels in your role hierarchy can lead to bad performance (including sharing calculation).
That is why we are giving you an alert if your hierarchy uses more that 7 levels .

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Analytics tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page lists all the reports and dashboards you can see in the current organization.

On all the tables:
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the item has no description, then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by descending Score, in other words the biggest scores come first.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Users tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page lists all your active users in the organization.

On this table :
  • Each row represents an active user
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the user is not using Lightning Experience, then you get +1.
    2. If the user never logged, , then you get +1.
  • The column Key Permission is focused on important permissions such as Api Enabled, View Setup,Modify All Data and View All Data.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Apex tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page lists all your Apex Classes and Triggers in four tabs:
  • The first tab called Classes is a tabular list of all the Apex Classes (not Tests) in this org.
  • The second tab called Triggers is a tabular list of all Apex Triggers in this org.
  • The third tab called Object's triggers count is a grouped table that aggregates all triggers per objects in this org.
  • The fourth tab called Unit Tests is a tabular list of all the Apex Test Classes in this org.

To make sure you get all the benefits from this page, make sure to follow these steps:
  1. You compile all classes by selecting the "Plug" button.
  2. You run all tests by selecting the "Like" button.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Custom Fields tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page lists all your custom fields and not the standard fields.

On this table :
  • Each row represents a custom field
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the field has no description, then you get +1.
    2. If the field is not used by any other entity (based on the Dependency API), then you get +1.
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.
  • If the field has dependencies, you can click on the link "Dependencies" to get a graphical view of where it isused and what it is using.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Custom Labels tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page lists all your custom labels .

On this table:
  • Each row represents a custom label
  • The column score is calculated based on the following rules:
    1. If the custom label is not used by any other entity (based on the Dependency API), then you get +1
  • By default, the table is ordered by Score descending, in other words the biggest scores come first.
  • If the field has dependencies, you can click on the link "Dependencies" to get a graphical view of where it is used and what it is using.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Profiles and Permission Sets tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page lists all your Profiles and Permission Sets in five tabs:
  • The first tab called Profiles is giving you a tabular list of all the profiles in this Org
  • The second tab called Permission Sets is giving you a tabular list of all the permission sets and permission set groups in this Org
  • The third tab called Login Hours Restrictions is extracting the login hour restrictions from all the profiles at once
  • The fourth tab called IP Range Restrictions is extracting the IP Range restrictions from all the profiles at once
  • The fifth tab called Object CRUDs (beta) is showing the rights (Create, Read, Update, Delete) on Objects for profiles and permission sets

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Public Groups tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page lists all your Public Groups and Queues in two tabs:
  • The first tab called Public Groups is giving you a tabular list of all the public groups in this Org
  • The second tab called Queues is giving you a tabular list of all the queues in this Org

The secret sauce in the page is the column called All Active Users which is calculated recurcively across all possible sub meta-groups (role, role and subordinates, groups, etc.) that are contained in the groups or queues.

labels.shortDescription: Description / Help text of the Visual Components tab in OrgCheck
labels.value:
This page lists all your Visual Components in five tabs:
  • The first tab called Visual Force Pages is a tabular list of all the VF pages in this org.
  • The second tab called Visual Force Components is a tabular list of all VF components in this org.
  • The third tab called Lightning Pages is a tabular list of all the Lightning pages (aka Flexi Pages for the ones that are deploying) in this org.
  • The fourth tab called Lightning Aura Components is a tabular list of all the Aura Components in this org.
  • The fifth tab called Lightning Web Components is a tabular list of all the LWC in this org.
Too many levels in your Role Hierarchy!

labels.shortDescription: Title of the Users tab in OrgCheck
Title of the Visual Components tab in OrgCheck
Subtitle of the Visual Components tab in OrgCheck
Subtitle #1 in section #1 in home page
Title of the Home tab in OrgCheck
Title of section #1 in home page
Subtitle of the Automations tab in OrgCheck
labels.value: Workflows, Process Builders and Flows Overview

You have more than {0} levels of roles in your Role Hierarchy (exactly {1} levels).
The Role Hierarchy is not there to mimic the hierarchy of your company, it is there to help manage record visibility.
Please reduce it!

You may have a Technical Debt , if you answer 'yes' to the following questions:
  • Is the performance of your Salesforce app low?
  • Is the time to resolve a bug long with your support?
  • Is maintenance cost increasing?
  • Is documentation about your Salesforce org poor?
  • Is adding new features getting more complex?
  • Is testing and/or deploying your app a nightmare?
  • If yes, you may have a technical debt that you need to reduce.
